awd_titl_txt: Multiconfigurational methods for copper cluster catalysts in copper-exchanged zeolites involved in methane-to-methanol conversion
awd_abstract_narration:
The United States has large reserves of natural gas, and the major component of this natural gas is methane. Methane is expensive to transport to locations where it can be utilized to make fuels and chemicals. Conversion of methane to methanol, a liquid and easily transported material, is one solution to this problem. To be economically feasible, the conversion of methane to methanol must be efficient. It must also occur using oxygen (air) and under practical conditions. Improved catalysts are needed for this reaction to be economically useful. Scientists have not yet discovered how to improve these catalysts, and it remains an unsolved problem and an active area of research. In this project, Dr. Samuel Odoh of the University of Nevada Reno is developing and using computational chemistry methods to understand exactly how these catalysts work and how to improve them. The new computational approaches being developed to solve this problem also have applications to other problems in chemistry and catalysis. The techniques and software being developed will be provided to the research community. Dr. Odoh and his group are providing education and research opportunities students from underrepresented groups and low-income families in Northern Nevada. These activities include summer research internships for high school students in Dr. Odoh's laboratory as well as outreach and recruitment drives to the inner-city areas of Reno-Tahoe. These activities are improving science, technology, engineering, and mathematics education at the middle school, high school and college levels.

With funding from the Chemical Catalysis Program of the Chemistry Division, Dr. Odoh of the University of Nevada Reno, is developing fundamental understanding of how the properties of copper-exchanged zeolites dictate their activity, turnover rates and selectivity in the oxidation of methane with oxygen to form methanol under mild temperature conditions. A theory-based understanding of the physical and chemical properties of these catalytic platforms can lead to improved predictions of materials with better performance for methane-to-methanol conversion (MMC). The researchers are developing and using new and existing quantum-mechanical methods capable of accurately describing the multireference properties of the metal oxide clusters that are the active sites for MMC. These methods are being used to investigate the nature and identity of the active sites in copper-exchanged zeolites. Dr. Odoh's laboratory is providing greater understanding of MMC and side-reactions in these materials. This work is guiding the design of better catalysts and leading to a pivot in the direction of developing catalysts for MMC. In addition, the computational techniques and software being developed will be provided to the research community for use in attacking other problems in chemistry and catalysis. Dr. Odoh is actively engaged in STEM outreach programs focused on recruiting students from low-income families and under-represented backgrounds. This is being done through high school student research internships, mentoring drives and educator development in support of the broader impacts of the project.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The NSF grant award 1800387 supported quantum-mechanical computational investigation of methane-to-methanol transformation by copper-exchanged zeolites. This project is mission-critical when one considers that the United States has abundant natural gas resources. The major component of natural gas is methane, a gas. This natural gas is transported over very large distances, to places where it will be used (homes, refineries, power plants ...e.t.c). For this reason, scientists have been interested in approaches for directly converting methane (again, a gas) to methanol (a liquid), under not-too-harsh conditions. The central idea is that methanol can be transported with existing infrastructure and that direct conversion is far less expensive than current liquefaction technologies.

For methane conversion to methanol (under reasonable conditions), the most selective systems are copper-exchanged zeolites. They are able to produce more methanol, instead of unwanted over-oxidation products like carbon dioxide, formic acid or carbon monoxide. The Odoh group used quantum-mechanical calculations to investigate copper-oxo active-site clusters in these zeolites. We used DFT and multiconfigurational approaches to investigate the reactivities of these sites, their electronic structures, how to improve their properties by mimicking nature's penchant for heterometallicity, influence of Br?nsted acid sites as well as their optical and X-ray absorption spectra. Over 5 years (07/2018-07/2023), researchers supported on this grant participated in 16 publications. One publication was a cover article. 

Intellectual Merits:

1) We provided the first detailed investigation of methane over-oxidation in copper-exchanged zeolites. This is crucially important as over-oxidation to unwanted CO2 and CO is one of the major factors mitigating against industrial adoption of direct methane-to-methanol conversion by copper-exchanged zeolites.

2) Detailed description of the relationships between methane over-oxidation and Bronsted active sites in copper-exchanged zeolites. We provided detailed explanations of how the methanol yield is affected by the amount of acid sites in the zeolites. Our predictions have now been confirmed experimentally.

3) We showed that theoretical methods can accurately predict the absorption spectra of copper species in zeolites. This is important as it now provides us a key to identify which species are actually doing the catalytic conversion of methane in these zeolites.

4) When we evaluated theoretical methods for spectra of these zeolites, we found that the best methods tend to be very expensive (take long time and resources to finish). For this reason, we developed a new density functional method that we demonstrated to be very good for predicting spectra of a large variety of chemical systems.

5) Described the mechanistic pathways by which the copper-oxo active sites in these zeolites are actually formed. We rationalized that if we know how they are formed and how they behave (1, 2 and 3 above), then we could progress to design catalysts that perform better. By performance, we were seeking catalysts that could be formed at a lower temperature (200 oC versus current 450 oC) and that still remained highly reactive and selective.

6) We examined the impact of heterometallicity on copper-exchanged zeolites. In our original proposal, we suggested that copying nature's "magic trick" of using two different metals in enzymes might be an opportunity to improve on copper-exchanged zeolites. We were able to show that replacing one or two copper atoms by silver or palladium will solve all the issues, however with the downside of being more expensive.

Broader Impacts:

1) This proposal supported four Ph.D. students over the entirety of their careers at the University of Nevada, Reno. Two of these are now continuing their careers as postdoctoral fellows (Adeyiga Olajumoke and Dipak Panthi) at other universities in the United States. Another Ph.D. student is now a professor (Olabisi Suleiman at Virginia Union University). The last student, Kevin Curtis is in his 4th year and will be graduating in May 2024. He was previously supported on this NSF grant but is now being supported on a NASA EPSCOR graduate scholarship.

2) This proposal allowed us to support several undergraduate students. Two of these are continued their careers as graduate students in Chemistry (Dillon Stetler at Oregon State University and Sirui Wang at University of California Riverside). Zoe Long is now a software engineer at Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory. Several other students (Janel Bustarde, Janel Reed, Shaina Bird and Corban King) have gone on with careers in medicine, dentistry, pharmacy and science laboratory technology. 

3) Outreach: Supported by this grant, the Odoh group regularly visited 5 high schools in the Reno-Tahoe basin (Reed High School, Carson High School, Fernley High School, Reno High School and Bishop Manogue High School) to meet with students, discuss chemical catalysis and recruit for the University of Nevada, Reno. We also provided research opportunities for several first generation TriO students (Vincent Lee, Juan Martinez and Celeste Rodriguez).
